unnormalised: In a surprising turn of events, the Delhi High Court has admitted a PIL challenging certain provisions of the newly amended Income Tax Act, 1961. The petition, filed by Adv. Mehra and Associates, alleges that Section 148A(d), specifically the part concerning reassessment notices, is causing undue hardship to small businesses.
normalised: In a surprising turn of events, the Delhi High Court has admitted a P-I-L challenging certain provisions of the newly amended Income Tax Act, one thousand nine hundred and sixty one. The petition, filed by Advocate Mehra and Associates, alleges that Section one hundred and forty eight A sub d, specifically the part concerning reassessment notices, is causing undue hardship to small businesses.

unnormalised: The PIL claims that the retrospective application of certain tax demands, dating back to assessment year 2015-16, is financially crippling many MSMEs, particularly those still recovering from the economic impact of COVID-19. Allegedly, notices were served on 31/03/2021, citing discrepancies under the old regime, now superseded by the amended act. The petitioners argue this creates legal ambiguity and invites arbitrary action by tax officials.
normalised: The P-I-L claims that the retrospective application of certain tax demands, dating back to assessment year two thousand and fifteen to sixteen, is financially crippling many M-S-M-Es, particularly those still recovering from the economic impact of C-O-V-I-D-nineteen. Allegedly, notices were served on thirty first march two thousand and twenty one, citing discrepancies under the old regime, now superseded by the amended act. The petitioners argue this creates legal ambiguity and invites arbitrary action by tax officials.

unnormalised: The government’s counsel, Mr. Sharma, argued that the amendments were designed to streamline tax administration and reduce litigation. He maintained that all actions are in accordance with the law and that adequate safeguards are in place to prevent harassment. The bench, comprising Justices Singh and Verma, however, observed that there appeared to be some merit in the petitioner's claim.
normalised: The government’s counsel, Mister Sharma, argued that the amendments were designed to streamline tax administration and reduce litigation. He maintained that all actions are in accordance with the law and that adequate safeguards are in place to prevent harassment. unnormalised: The court has issued a notice to the Central Board of Direct Taxes (CBDT), seeking a detailed response within 4 weeks. The next hearing is scheduled for 15/07/2024. The CBDT is expected to clarify its position on the application of Section 148A(d) to past assessment years.
normalised: The court has issued a notice to the Central Board of Direct Taxes (C-B-D-T), seeking a detailed response within four weeks. The next hearing is scheduled for fifteenth July two thousand and twenty four. The C-B-D-T is expected to clarify its position on the application of Section one hundred and forty eight A sub d to past assessment years.

unnormalised: Meanwhile, tax experts are divided on the issue. CA. Rajesh Gupta believes that a balanced approach is necessary to protect both the government’s revenue interests and the rights of taxpayers. He suggested a threshold limit of, say, Rs. 50,000 for demanding taxes retrospectively to protect vulnerable entities.
normalised: Meanwhile, tax experts are divided on the issue. unnormalised: The outcome of this case could have significant implications for thousands of taxpayers across India. Many are anxiously awaiting the court's decision, hoping for relief from what they see as oppressive tax demands. The case, numbered WP(C) 5678/2024, promises to be a landmark judgment in tax law.

unnormalised: Adding to the complexity, a similar petition was filed in the Bombay HC last week, challenging the same provisions. The petitioner in that case, Mr. Patel, a textile merchant from Surat, claims to have received a reassessment notice demanding Rs. 2.5 lakh, based on transactions dating back to FY 2017-18. The legal battle is expected to intensify in the coming weeks.
